Abstract: Given the increasing complexity of transportation systems and the critical need for effective safety oversight, this study aims to evaluate and improve the transportation safety supervision (TSS) system in Henan Province, China. Based on questionnaire data from relevant units in Henan Province, China, a three-level index system of the effectiveness of TSS consisting of 4 criterion-level indicators and 25 factory-level indicators is established. By combining the analytic hierarchy process (AHP) and grey system theory, a hierarchical grey evaluation model is constructed to evaluate the current situation of TSS in Henan Province. The results show that the evaluation index system and the weights of each index are reliable. The comprehensive evaluation value of the TSS system in Henan Province is 3.08, indicating that the effectiveness of the system is at level 2; thus, the current situation of TSS in Henan Province is good. Based on the calculated evaluation values of the first- and second-level indicators, suggestions are put forward to strengthen the management of the TSS by supervision units at all levels. With the rapid development of the social economy, new demands for safety production have been made. The transportation industry is the foundation of economic growth, and safety is the top priority in transportation and transit systems [1]. Despite recent improvements in traffic safety in China, including decreases in the numbers of accidents and fatalities, the problem of traffic safety remains severe [2], and there are many concerns about ensuring efficiency, low accident rates, and smooth transportation services. Safety has been at the forefront of transportation planning for over a decade and will continue to play an essential role [3,4]. Recent years have witnessed notable advancements in safety evaluation, due in part to the widespread adoption of sophisticated evaluation methodologies [5]. Lomakinet et al. proposed a method for the evaluation of traffic safety rooted in multi- criteria evaluation [6]. This approach enables the development of a structured, hierarchical system for the assessment of traffic safety levels in various regions, thereby facilitating a more comprehensive understanding of traffic safety dynamics. Chandrasekaran et al. explored the environment of the road transport system from several perspectives [7]; they pinpointed critical factors within the road environment that significantly influence road transport and proceeded to craft a sophisticated safety evaluation model. In order to evaluate urban road traffic safety, Wang et al. selected several major influencing factors, such as pavement condition, traffic isolation, monitoring Settings, congestion degree, accident rate, and tunnel Settings [8]. Luo et al. established an evaluation model for the safety state of urban traffic using a fuzzy algorithm with people, vehicles, roads, and the environment as evaluation indices [9]. Li established the multi-level safety evaluation index system based on expressway linearity and established the expressway linear comprehensive safety evaluation model based on extension theory; additionally, the entropy weight method was used to determine the weight of each index and classify the safety level [10]. Based on driving behavior data, Min uses the AHP and fuzzy comprehensive evaluation method to determine the safety state of road traffic [11]. Mbakwe et al. used Delphi technology and a Bayesian network (BN) model to evaluate national highway traffic safety [12]. Mohan et al. and Wang et al. studied the evaluation method of urban traffic safety based on accident rate [13,14]. While these studies have made significant strides in researching and analyzing safety evaluation methods, additional research that focuses explicitly on evaluation systems for transportation safety supervision (TSS) is required. TSS comprises the various measures and systems adopted to ensure that the trans- portation industry complies with relevant laws and regulations in the production process. The goals of TSS are to prevent personal injury, property damage, production accidents, and various hazards, and to ensure the safe production of enterprises and the regular operation of transportation facilities. TSS represents a multifaceted and dynamic system comprising numerous interacting factors. To accurately gauge its regulatory effectiveness, pinpoint existing weaknesses and hidden risks, and develop targeted strategies for their mitigation, correction, and prevention, it is imperative to establish a comprehensive evaluation system that thoroughly accounts for these diverse factors. The efficacy of TSS can be adeptly assessed via these qualitative indicators.

Presently, the most commonly employed techniques in safety evaluation include the AHP, fuzzy mathematics, and grey system theory [15–17]. Fuzzy mathematics has emerged as a robust and efficient mechanism for knowledge reasoning in scenarios fraught with uncertainty [18]. Grey system theory excels in navigating uncertain information systems and is particularly effective in modeling contexts where data are scarce or incomplete. The AHP stands out as a versatile decision-making approach that facilitates the relative prioritization and assessment of various options across multiple criteria [19]. Since its inception, the AHP has found widespread applications across virtually all decision-making domains [20], making it a multi-criteria decision-making instrument of broad utility [21]. Sarbast Moslem [48] developed a novel simplified AHP, known as P-AHP, within a spherical fuzzy environ- ment to provide sustainable and efficient solutions for improving the public bus transport system in Dublin, Ireland. This method integrates P-AHP and spherical fuzzy sets (SF sets) within a unified framework, offering a more robust approach to addressing complex urban transportation issues. By introducing spherical fuzzy sets, decision-makers can express their preferences and uncertainties more comprehensively, thereby enhancing the reliability and accuracy of decision-making. The P-SF-AHP model is scalable and suitable for addressing larger-scale and more intricate urban transportation planning problems. [49] employed a novel spherical decision model to assess the degree of preference separation among driving behavior factors associated with road traffic accidents. The use of spherical fuzzy sets allowed for the representation of drivers’ preferences for different behavioral factors, considering the distribution of preferences on a circular scale. This evaluation method enhances our understanding of the relationship between driver behavior and road safety. By quantitatively assessing driver behavior factors, we can determine the extent of drivers’ preferences for different behavioral factors, which aids in understanding their focus and priorities regarding road safety. Moreover, employing spherical fuzzy sets improves the accuracy of evaluations and provides a better reflection of drivers’ preference distributions, further strengthening our comprehension of the re- lationship between driver behavior and road safety. The study utilized the grey AHP method to assess the importance of primary criteria and sub-criteria and employed the grey MOORA method to evaluate various alternative solutions for public transportation services. The grey MOORA method addresses multi-objective optimization problems by comparing and ranking differ- ent alternative solutions to identify the optimal one. However, it should be noted that the results of the grey AHP-MOORA model are presented as grey numbers, which may add complexity and pose challenges for interpretation. The model developed in this study can support strategic decision-making plans aimed at enhancing urban transport systems and has potential applicability to public transportation systems in other countries and cities as well. Sarbast Moslem, Muhammet Gul et al. [51] employed a method that combines the best–worst method (BWM) and triangular fuzzy sets to rank and prioritize critical driving behavior guidelines. Initially, the F-BWM model was used to assess driving behavior factors and calculate weight scores. Subsequently, the reliability of the prioritization crite- ria was validated by examining consistency within the F-BWM framework. Throughout this process, fuzzy reference comparison and fuzzy preference were utilized to identify the most and least important factors. Following this, a nonlinear constrained model was applied to compute optimal fuzzy weights for all primary factors. Ultimately, consistency ratios were computed to evaluate result coherence. This integrated approach, utilizing the BWM and triangular fuzzy sets for ranking and prioritization, helps to reduce evaluation time and comparison frequency while enhancing overall model efficiency. However, it is worth noting that the BWM may become intricate and challenging when dealing with large decision problems. Additionally, these methods require suitable data inputs and parameter selection, and the BWM’s effectiveness relies on decision-makers’ professional knowledge and experience. Insufficient expertise or experience among decision-makers could potentially impact decision accuracy. Consequently, careful consideration in selecting these methods, along with thorough result interpretation and integration with real-world contexts, is imperative during application. In the study conducted by Muhammed Ordu and Oguzhan Der [52], the AHP was effectively utilized for selecting manufacturing ma- terials for flexible pulsating heat pipes (FPHPs). A multi-level decision-making model was established to decompose the material selection process into a structured hierarchy considerations of environmental sustainability. By employing this methodology, the study not only enhanced the transparency of the decision-making process but also ensured the rationality and effectiveness of the final outcomes. In their 2024 study, Bulut, M.S., Ordu, M., Der, O., and Basar, G. [53] introduced a systematic approach to selecting thermoplastic materials for hybrid vehicle battery packs by leveraging comparative MCDM methods. To ensure that the selected materials met both technical requirements and sustainability goals, the SWARA method was employed to determine the importance weights of the eval- uation criteria. SWARA allocated these weights by systematically comparing the relative significance of each criterion against others, thus providing a robust quantitative frame- work for material selection. In the decision-making phase, three MCDM methods—ARAS, EDAS, and TOPSIS—were applied to evaluate and rank the thermoplastic materials. The ARAS method established a direct link between the utility functions of alternatives and the influence of primary criteria, while the EDAS method assessed alternatives based on positive and negative distances to an average solution. TOPSIS evaluated the alternatives by measuring their proximity to the ideal best and worst solutions. The adoption of these methods was motivated by their effectiveness in addressing complex decision-making chal- lenges, particularly those involving multiple and often conflicting criteria. By holistically considering performance, safety, and sustainability, the study provided valuable insights for manufacturers in material selection and laid a solid foundation for future research into emerging materials and decision-making frameworks. Furthermore, the proposed approach contributes to the sustainable development of hybrid vehicle technologies, with significant implications for material selection in the automotive industry.

While previous research has explored various multi-criteria decision-making methods (such as the AHP, fuzzy logic, and grey system theory) in transportation projects, there has been limited application of these methods specifically to the evaluation of transportation safety supervision effectiveness. The main contribution of this research lies in the devel- opment of a comprehensive evaluation index system, incorporating both criterion-level and factor-level indicators. By combining grey system theory with AHP, a hierarchical grey evaluation model is constructed, offering a novel approach to systematically assess transportation safety supervision. This study provides a validated, quantifiable framework that can be applied in future evaluations, along with practical suggestions for improving safety supervision practices based on the empirical findings. This study addresses the evaluation of TSS, an important but underexplored area in transportation research. As transportation networks become increasingly complex, effective safety supervision is critical to ensure public safety and efficient operation. While much of the existing research has concentrated on transportation project planning and prioritization, there has been a lack of systematic evaluation specifically targeting the effectiveness of safety supervision. This study fills that gap by developing a tailored evaluation model based on the grey AHP for assessing TSS in Henan Province. The proposed framework not only provides a quantitative tool to measure the performance of safety supervision but also helps identify areas of weakness in the current system. The necessity of such an evaluation is clear: ensuring safety supervision is not only vital for public protection but also for optimizing resource allocation in regulatory practices, especially in the face of evolving transportation challenges. The grey AHP, which integrates grey theory with AHP, facilitates a comprehensive consideration of multiple evaluation indicators and mitigates the influence of expert subjective judgments on outcomes. Utilizing the grey AHP for assessing the traffic safety supervision system involves incorporating grey processing into weights and decision matrices while accounting for uncertain factors during the evaluation process. This approach helps to reduce subjectivity in evaluations and enhance the reliability of assessment results. The grey AHP is adept at synthesizing disparate information into weighted vectors that represent various degrees of uncertainty, thereby converting them into a unified format. This method has demonstrated considerable efficacy in system evaluation and analysis, providing valuable insights in complex evaluative contexts [54]. Approaching from a systems engineering perspective, the present research delves into the many factors critical for the evaluation of TSS. Drawing on the real-world context provided by a safety supervision survey questionnaire completed by transportation industry authorities of Henan Province, China, the AHP is utilized to devise an evaluation model for TSS. This model includes a comprehensive set of indicators that influence the assessment of the current state of TSS. Furthermore, the TSS landscape in Henan Province is exhaustively evaluated by integrating the principles of grey system theory. This thorough examination offers vital insights and a substantial reference for the evaluation of, and decision-making processes in, TSS. The comprehensive evaluation of TSS via the grey AHP and the mathematical thinking process can clarify the analysis process and improve the scientificity of the results. The remainder of this paper is organized as follows: Section 2 introduces the methods and models used for evaluating the transportation supervision system and establishes the evaluation framework. Section 3 presents a case study, including the calculation and analysis of the evaluation results. Section 4 provides a discussion of the evaluation results and offers recommendations based on the findings. Finally, Section 5 concludes this study by summarizing the key outcomes. The construction of the evaluation index system for TSS is predicated on an in-depth understanding of the actual state of safety production in the transport sector, which is intertwined with established theories of safety supervision and evaluation. Adhering to the principles of systematicity, scientificity, objectivity, and comprehensiveness [55], this system not only facilitates a rational analysis of the TSS system, but also ensures that the selection and determination of evaluation indicators comprehensively encapsulate the impact of a multitude of objective factors. To comprehensively reflect the status quo of TSS in Henan Province, the overall status quo of TSS supervision units at all levels, the status quo of the supervision subjects, the status quo of the production base, the level of supervision, and the status quo of the safety production service capacity are investigated. According to a survey, the overall situation of the TSS by supervision units at all levels mainly includes the commendation situation, the safety hidden danger situation, and overall self-rating. The current situation of the main body of supervision mainly involves the organization, the supervision content, personnel and equipment funding problems, the management level, etc. The basic component of safety production mainly consists of the number of transportation enterprises, the standardization of safety production, the situation of full-time safety personnel, and the occurrence of accidents and casualties in the transportation field. Finally, the supervision level and safety production service ability mainly include the responsibilities of safety management, problems in safety supervision performance assessment methods, and key considerations.

The primary respondents of this questionnaire survey were transportation bureaus from prefecture-level cities and directly administered county-level cities in Henan Province. The survey covered various unit types, including safety management departments, trans- portation management departments, construction management departments, and other related entities, reflecting the core functional areas of transportation authorities. Of the respondents, 50% were from safety management departments, while over 38% represented transportation management departments. A total of 25 questionnaires were distributed, yielding 24 valid responses, with an effective response rate exceeding 95%. Respondents included 9 unit directors, 7 safety management leaders, 4 department heads, and 4 general staff members, with an average age of 35 years. Notably, department heads and safety management leaders comprised more than 65% of the total respondents. Therefore, the content of the questionnaire is not only accurate and reliable, but also has strong authority. This has a guiding effect on the construction of the TSS evaluation index system while avoiding the emergence of impractical evaluation indicators or evaluation requirements Based on the AHP, with reference to the Production Safety Law, via data research and expert consultation, and in comprehensive consideration of the actual situation of the TSS system, the status of TSS was taken as the target layer. Four primary indicators, namely, the overall status of TSS by units at all levels, the status of the supervision subjects, the base of production at the grassroots level, and the supervision level and status of production safety serviceability, constituted the criterion layer. According to the comprehensive safety assessment value obtained in the previous step, the current TSS system in Henan Province can be judged as being in overall good condition. However, in actual production, decision-makers must know not only the overall safety level of the evaluation system, but also which aspects of the entire system are sufficient, and which aspects could be stronger. It is necessary to know the evaluation values of indicators at all levels to determine the advantages and weaknesses of the current TSS system in Henan Province, and ultimately to take corresponding rectification measures to improve the safety status. The results demonstrate that the overall evaluation of the effectiveness of the current TSS system in Henan Province is level 2, indicating a good state. The results show that under the current transport supervision system, the TSS departments at all levels in Henan Province perform their duties well; thus, the current form of TSS in the province is in a safe state. However, some aspects still exhibit deficiencies. The TSS departments in some counties and cities in Henan Province are not clear about the division of the supervision content with their neighboring cities and counties, indicating a vague scope of work. Furthermore, the annual safety funding and equipment of the TSS departments of some areas of Henan Province do not meet the needs of daily supervision work. Therefore, the TSS departments should increase the annual safety production funds of each unit and improve vehicles and other equipment to meet these needs. By calculating the evaluation values of the primary and secondary indicators, the evaluation value of each index is obtained. From the result table, it can be observed that the overall situation of TSS at all levels of unit B1 scores higher than that of unit B2. According to Table 4, the evaluation value of unit B1 is the highest among the primary indicators, while the evaluation value of unit B2 is lower. This indicates that although the overall situation of traffic safety supervision and management at all levels of the units is good, there is still a need to strengthen the management of TSS subjects at all levels. The evaluation values of each secondary indicator in Table 5 are relatively high. From Table 6, it can be seen that the evaluation values of C21, C213, and C22 are lower, suggesting that the traffic safety supervision units at all levels should establish a safety production committee and hold regular safety meetings. This approach enhances the management and supervision of safety production in the transportation field, improving the ability to prevent accidents and respond to emergencies. Regular safety meetings facilitate the prompt dissemination of relevant policies, regulations, case studies, and the latest safety technology information, promoting the sharing of experiences and learning among industry peers. This approach not only provides valuable reference experience for various countries and cities but also fosters cross-regional and cross-industry coop- eration and exchange. The grey hierarchical analysis model is a multi-factor, multi-level decision-making method with broad applicability in transportation safety supervision. This model enables the systematic and scientific evaluation and analysis of various factors in- volved in transportation safety supervision. By conducting in-depth research and analysis of the actual situations in different regions and integrating the scientific evaluation methods offered by the grey hierarchical analysis model, we can identify and address numerous issues in the field of transportation. The establishment of the transportation safety supervi- sion evaluation system and the selection of indicators in this study can serve as a reference for relevant departments. Transportation safety remains a prominent societal issue. With the acceleration of urbanization, the increasing number of vehicles, and the expansion of road construction, traffic management faces increasingly complex and severe challenges. Therefore, establishing a scientific and reasonable transportation safety supervision evalua- tion system is of paramount importance. In practice, relevant departments can refer to the methods and experiences proposed in this study and make appropriate adjustments based on local characteristics and actual conditions before implementing them. The evaluation results of the grey hierarchical model for the transportation safety supervision system offer valuable insights for relevant departments, aiding them in identifying the shortcomings of the current transportation supervision system and formulating targeted improvement mea- sures. Additionally, this study can encourage relevant departments to enhance information sharing, communication, and cooperation mechanisms, fostering a multi-party linkage and comprehensive governance approach. This approach will contribute to achieving smooth roads, orderly traffic, and safe pedestrian travel, and to establishing a more effective and sustainable transportation management system.

This study developed a grey hierarchical analysis evaluation model, exemplified it via specific cases, and identified the indicators and factors within the model, which is characterized by a well-defined hierarchy and clear structure. The following conclusions were drawn from the findings: Via the evaluation of the primary and secondary indicators, the weak points of the TSS system were revealed, and the results indicate that the management of the TSS bodies at all levels should be strengthened.
